THE NEWS LETTER
BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 6, 1911.

VOL. XVI, NO. 5.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

HOPKINS MEN AS WATCHERS

ALUMNI ON THE TICKETS

NEW FIELD AT HOMEWOOD

HOPKINS DOWNS GALLAUDET

Members of University to Scrutinize the
Count Tomorrow Night—Dr.
Bliss' Experiences.

Hopkins Supporters Gratified to See Such
a Goodly Sprinkling Among the
List of Candidates.

To Be Used for Practice on Bad Days
and Just Before Big Games.
Recent Changes.

Mutes Play a Snappy Game, Holding the
Black and Blue to a 12 to 0
Score Fulton Stars.

The Johns Hopkins University
is going to be well represented
among the Reform League watchers
in the election tomorrow. Among
those who will act as watchers are
Dr. R. V. D. Magoffin, associate
in history; Franklin Edgerton,
Johnston scholar in Sanscrit ; Walter Johnson, graduate student in
history; John T. Holmes, general
secretary of the Hopkins Y. M.
C. A.; Leo Wolman, graduate stu.dent in economics; Dr. S. F. Acree,
associate professor of chemistry;
Dr. J. S. Guy, assistant in physical
chemistry; H. H. Lubs, graduate
student in chemistry, and
A.
Blossom, instructor in Romance languages. Dr. Kirby F. *Smith, Dr.
Lovejoy, and Dr. E. C. Armstrong
will also probably be watchers. With
'such a galaxy of Hopkins men, there
should be a fair count in the precincts to which they are assigned.
The Professors and students may
have some thrilling experiences, especially those in some of the South
Baltimore precincts. Dr. W. J. A.
Bliss, who was a watcher in an election in 1905, had an experience
which he has never forgotten. He
was on duty at Lombard and Hanover streets, in the Fourth Precinct
of the Ninth Ward(since changed),
from nine o'clock to one. Nothing of
importance happened until about ten
minutes of one, when the Republican
watcher asked Dr. Bliss to accompany a policeman, who was about
to arrest a man for illegitimate voting. Dr. Bliss was to see that the
Policeman, who may have been, by
some mere chance, under the influence of the organization, did not
let the man loose as soon as they
were around the corner from the
polls. The three men started to
the station house, but around the
corner on Hanover street, four men,
of the big-jaw variety, demanded
that the prisoner be set free. The
policeman drew his club and ordered
the ruffians to stand off. But without a word of warning, they attacked him and bore him to the
pavement.
Dr. Bliss was the only man in
sight, and seeing that the officer's
safety depended upon him, he drew
two of the bullies off and seized
one by the throat. By this time
People crossing Hanover at Baltimore and German streets saw the
scuffle and ran to the struggling
heap. The four big-jaws then made
their escape down German street.

Edmund B. Lowndes, A. B., '10,
is one of the Democratic candidates
for the House of Delegates from
Howard county.
Thomas G. Campbell, A. B., 'o6,
is one *of the Democratic candidates
for the House of Delegates from
Baltimore county,
Ogle Marbury, A. B. 202, is one
of the Democratic candidates for
the House of Delegates from Prince
George's county.
William H. Maltbie, Ph.D., '95,
from Baltimore city, is a Republican candidate for the House of Delegates from the Second Legislative
District.
Morris A. Soper, A. B., '93, is
the Republican candidate for Attorney-General from Baltimore city.
• Lindsay C. Spencer, A. B.,'oi, is
one of the Republican candidates
for Judge , of the Orphans' Court
of Baltimore city.
Henry A. Whitaker, A. B., '95,
has been nominated by the Republicans of Harford and Baltimore
counties as their candidate for Associate Judge of the Third Judicial
Circuit.
It is to be regretted that more
college men in Maryland do not
run for political offices. All the
Hopkins supporters, however, will
be gratified to see such a goodly
sprinkling of Hopkins graduates
among the list of candidates. The
University has been accused of educating men "out of the State"—that
is, not making them show any interest in the body politic of the
State, or caring about administering to the State affairs. Surely the
men on the above list are doing their
best to stop such an idea from getting into the minds of our representatives at Annapolis. May the
list of Hopkins men running for
office next year be twice as long,
and may they do their best to aid
the interests of the University
among the law-makers.

The authorities in charge of
Homewood grounds of the University have been busy lately preparing
the tract for the buildings. Most
of the work done up to the present
consists of grading and excavating.
At the side of the main athletic
field, along the boulevard, near
Charles street; a fine, new practice
field has been made. It is large and
will be used for practice on bad
days or on days before big games,
so that the main field can be kept
in good shape, as it is hard on the
turf to have three teams practicing
nearly all the year. It will be used
mainly by the baseball team. There
is some talk also of turfing it completely and laying out about 15 tennis courts to be used in the summer
after the practices are over.
If this should be done, the University will then be as properly
equipped for tennis as it is for other
sports. It should also create more
interest in tennis, as the present
courts are woefully inadequate to
handle the large number of players.
In addition to these probable
courts, there are three sure turf
ones which will be in prime condition for next year. They are also
along the boulevard, but at the other
end, right at the entrance to Wyman Park, and alongside of the 220yard straightaway.
The turf on
them has been growing now for
two years, and has a good start.
Another improvement which has
been made is the excavation of a
large bowl in front of the Carroll
Mansion on Charles street, where
the main entrance to the University
grounds will be. The earth from
this bowl has been used to fill the
athletic field, to level up a lot cif
ground in the middle of the estate
and to build a number of causeways
through the woods.
Another important improvement
is the big addition to the plant laboratory, which has been put up in
the center of the tract. The laboratory and greenhouse were built
several years ago, but have now
been so much out-grown. that an
addition much larger than the original has been constructed.
This is really the prettiest part of
the estate, as the botanical department has made a beautiful garden
out in front of, the conservatories.
The garden is about as large as a
city block. In the center is a large
concrete pool.

Hopkins had no difficulty in defeating the deaf mutes, on Saturday at Homewood, although the
'Varsity was unable to pile up as
large a score as was expected.
The first score was made after
four minutes of play. Gillet kicked
and the punt was carried back 15
yards by Moore. Hopkins lost the
ball on downs. Hopkins regained
possession of the pigskin after futile attempts by the visitors to gain.
Fulton tried right end for a gain
of 25 yards on a fake kick. The
ball was advanced to Gallaudet's
15-yard line on the next play. Fulton kicked a goal from field, the
ball going straight over the bar and
between the uprights.
In the third period, with the ball
in Hopkins' possession, a forward
pass from Gillet to Branham netted
15 yards, but Gillet was forced to
kick on the third down. Gallaudet
attempted an end run, but the ball
was fumbled and recovered by Gittings. No gain was made on Gillet's attempt through center. On
Gallaudet's 30-yard line, Fulton
kicked a field goal, the ball going
directly over the bar.
In the fourth period, Hopkins
had two chances to score a touchdown, one of which was successful.
Gillet gained 5 yards through the
center, and a forward pass increased the distance by 20 yards.
With the ball on the deaf mutes'
io-yard line, Bridgman made first
down. Two more yards were made
through center, but Hopkins was
unable to break throilg-h the visitor's wall, and the ball went over
on the mutes' 3-yard line. Gallaudet kicked. On the next play,
Catlin made 10 yards on an end.
run. Fulton received a forward
pass, and crossed the line with the
pigskin after a run of 20 yards.

Lectures

on "Sleep."

Dr. Max Verworn, professor of
physiology in the University of
Bonn, lectured, Wednesday afternoon, before the Scientific Association, on "Sleep." The Doctor said
that although he had a sleepy theme,
he hoped his audience would not
put his theories of sleep into practice until later.
Dr. Verworn said he does not believe in the prophetic power of
dreams. He thinks that they are an
extension of the process of activity
which goes on in waking hours.

Professor Wilson to Travel.

Professor Harry L. Wilson, the
head of the Roman Archaeological
Department of the University, left
Baltimore, Friday, for a threeweeks' lecture tour. The subject of
his lectures will be, "Ancient Cities
of Etruria and Their Buried Treasure."
Dr. Wilson is lecturing under the
auspices of the Archwlogical Institute of America, of which he is
an officer.
While he is away, Dr. Wilson
will go as far north and east as
Halifax N. S., and as far west as
St. Paul. He will speak not only
before the various societies of the
Archxological Institute, but also in
universities, including the University of Illinois and the University
of Wisconsin.
Chess Club Officers.

A meeting was held, Friday afternoon, in Levering Hall, to elect
officers for the Chess Club for the
coming year.
The officers are: President, W.
E. Pearce; Vice-President, B.
Benedict; Secretary-Treasurer, A.
S. Hammond.
It is intended to have a "live"
organization this year. Already the
boards are being brought out and
members can be seen practicing for
the major and minor tournaments,
which will begin soon. One of the
most interested players is Mr. Yokoyama, a Jananese, at the University.
Beside the major and minor
tournaments, the best of the Hopkins players will meet the University of Pennsylvania team either
over the boards or by correspondence. The minor chess team will
have • monthly matches—probably
with City College and Polytechnic.
The interclass match will be held
after Christmas. Last year, the
freshmen beat the sophomores by
the score of 8 to 1.

THE NEWS LETTER

HOPKINS MEN AS WATCHERS

ALUMNI ON THE TICKETS

NEW FIELD AT HOMEWOOD

HOPKINS DOWNS GALLAUDET

Members of University to Scrutinize the
Count Tomorrow Night—Dr.
Bliss' Experiences.

Hopkins Supporters Gratified to See Such
a Goodly Sprinkling Among the
List of Candidates.

To Be Used for Practice on Bad Days
and Just Before Big Games.
Recent Changes.

Mutes Play a Snappy Game, Holding the
Black and Blue to a 12 to 0
Score Fulton Stars.

The Johns Hopkins University
is going to be well represented
among the Reform League watchers
in the election tomorrow. Among
those who will act as watchers are
Dr. R. V. D. Magoffin, associate
in history; Franklin Edgerton,
Johnston scholar in Sanscrit ; Walter Johnson, graduate student in
history; John T. Holmes, general
secretary of the Hopkins Y. M.
C. A.; Leo Wolman, graduate stu.dent in economics; Dr. S. F. Acree,
associate professor of chemistry;
Dr. J. S. Guy, assistant in physical
chemistry; H. H. Lubs, graduate
student in chemistry, and
A.
Blossom, instructor in Romance languages. Dr. Kirby F. *Smith, Dr.
Lovejoy, and Dr. E. C. Armstrong
will also probably be watchers. With
'such a galaxy of Hopkins men, there
should be a fair count in the precincts to which they are assigned.
The Professors and students may
have some thrilling experiences, especially those in some of the South
Baltimore precincts. Dr. W. J. A.
Bliss, who was a watcher in an election in 1905, had an experience
which he has never forgotten. He
was on duty at Lombard and Hanover streets, in the Fourth Precinct
of the Ninth Ward(since changed),
from nine o'clock to one. Nothing of
importance happened until about ten
minutes of one, when the Republican
watcher asked Dr. Bliss to accompany a policeman, who was about
to arrest a man for illegitimate voting. Dr. Bliss was to see that the
Policeman, who may have been, by
some mere chance, under the influence of the organization, did not
let the man loose as soon as they
were around the corner from the
polls. The three men started to
the station house, but around the
corner on Hanover street, four men,
of the big-jaw variety, demanded
that the prisoner be set free. The
policeman drew his club and ordered
the ruffians to stand off. But without a word of warning, they attacked him and bore him to the
pavement.
Dr. Bliss was the only man in
sight, and seeing that the officer's
safety depended upon him, he drew
two of the bullies off and seized
one by the throat. By this time
People crossing Hanover at Baltimore and German streets saw the
scuffle and ran to the struggling
heap. The four big-jaws then made
their escape down German street.

from Baltimore city, is a Republican candidate for the House of Delegates from the Second Legislative
District.
Morris A. Soper, A. B., '93, is
the Republican candidate for Attorney-General from Baltimore city.
• Lindsay C. Spencer, A. B.,'oi, is
one of the Republican candidates
for Judge , of the Orphans' Court
of Baltimore city.
Henry A. Whitaker, A. B., '95,
has been nominated by the Republicans of Harford and Baltimore
counties as their candidate for Associate Judge of the Third Judicial
Circuit.
It is to be regretted that more
college men in Maryland do not
run for political offices. All the
Hopkins supporters, however, will
be gratified to see such a goodly
sprinkling of Hopkins graduates
among the list of candidates. The
University has been accused of educating men "out of the State"—that
is, not making them show any interest in the body politic of the
State, or caring about administering to the State affairs. Surely the
men on the above list are doing their
best to stop such an idea from getting into the minds of our representatives at Annapolis. May the
list of Hopkins men running for
office next year be twice as long,
and may they do their best to aid
the interests of the University
among the law-makers.

The authorities in charge of
Homewood grounds of the University have been busy lately preparing
the tract for the buildings. Most
of the work done up to the present
consists of grading and excavating.
At the side of the main athletic
field, along the boulevard, near
Charles street; a fine, new practice
field has been made. It is large and
will be used for practice on bad
days or on days before big games,
so that the main field can be kept
in good shape, as it is hard on the
turf to have three teams practicing
nearly all the year. It will be used
mainly by the baseball team. There
is some talk also of turfing it completely and laying out about 15 tennis courts to be used in the summer
after the practices are over.
If this should be done, the University will then be as properly
equipped for tennis as it is for other
sports. It should also create more
interest in tennis, as the present
courts are woefully inadequate to
handle the large number of players.
In addition to these probable
courts, there are three sure turf
ones which will be in prime condition for next year. They are also
along the boulevard, but at the other
end, right at the entrance to Wyman Park, and alongside of the 220yard straightaway.
The turf on
them has been growing now for
two years, and has a good start.
Another improvement which has
been made is the excavation of a
large bowl in front of the Carroll
Mansion on Charles street, where
the main entrance to the University
grounds will be. The earth from
this bowl has been used to fill the
athletic field, to level up a lot cif
ground in the middle of the estate
and to build a number of causeways
through the woods.
Another important improvement
is the big addition to the plant laboratory, which has been put up in
the center of the tract. The laboratory and greenhouse were built
several years ago, but have now
been so much out-grown. that an
addition much larger than the original has been constructed.
This is really the prettiest part of
the estate, as the botanical department has made a beautiful garden
out in front of, the conservatories.
The garden is about as large as a
city block. In the center is a large
concrete pool.

Hopkins had no difficulty in defeating the deaf mutes, on Saturday at Homewood, although the
'Varsity was unable to pile up as
large a score as was expected.
The first score was made after
four minutes of play. Gillet kicked
and the punt was carried back 15
yards by Moore. Hopkins lost the
ball on downs. Hopkins regained
possession of the pigskin after futile attempts by the visitors to gain.
Fulton tried right end for a gain
of 25 yards on a fake kick. The
ball was advanced to Gallaudet's
15-yard line on the next play. Fulton kicked a goal from field, the
ball going straight over the bar and
between the uprights.
In the third period, with the ball
in Hopkins' possession, a forward
pass from Gillet to Branham netted
15 yards, but Gillet was forced to
kick on the third down. Gallaudet
attempted an end run, but the ball
was fumbled and recovered by Gittings. No gain was made on Gillet's attempt through center. On
Gallaudet's 30-yard line, Fulton
kicked a field goal, the ball going
directly over the bar.
In the fourth period, Hopkins
had two chances to score a touchdown, one of which was successful.
Gillet gained 5 yards through the
center, and a forward pass increased the distance by 20 yards.
With the ball on the deaf mutes'
io-yard line, Bridgman made first
down. Two more yards were made
through center, but Hopkins was
unable to break throilg-h the visitor's wall, and the ball went over
on the mutes' 3-yard line. Gallaudet kicked. On the next play,
Catlin made 10 yards on an end.
run. Fulton received a forward
pass, and crossed the line with the
pigskin after a run of 20 yards.

Lectures

on "Sleep."

Dr. Max Verworn, professor of
physiology in the University of
Bonn, lectured, Wednesday afternoon, before the Scientific Association, on "Sleep." The Doctor said
that although he had a sleepy theme,
he hoped his audience would not
put his theories of sleep into practice until later.
Dr. Verworn said he does not believe in the prophetic power of
dreams. He thinks that they are an
extension of the process of activity
which goes on in waking hours.

Dr. Keidel Has Resigned.

Dr. George C. Keidel, formerly
associate in Romaiice languages,
has .been connected with the Congressional Library since September.
He graduated from the Hopkins
in 1889. From 1893-1895, he held
a fellowship here, and in 1905 he
took his doctor's degree. For several years he was associate in Romance languages in this University,
resigning only last September. In
1908 lie was elected corresponding
member of the Hispanic Society of
America.

Professor Wilson to Travel.

Professor Harry L. Wilson, the
head of the Roman Archaeological
Department of the University, left
Baltimore, Friday, for a threeweeks' lecture tour. The subject of
his lectures will be, "Ancient Cities
of Etruria and Their Buried Treasure."
Dr. Wilson is lecturing under the
auspices of the Archwlogical Institute of America, of which he is
an officer.
While he is away, Dr. Wilson
will go as far north and east as
Halifax N. S., and as far west as
St. Paul. He will speak not only
before the various societies of the
Archxological Institute, but also in
universities, including the University of Illinois and the University
of Wisconsin.
Chess Club Officers.

A meeting was held, Friday afternoon, in Levering Hall, to elect
officers for the Chess Club for the
coming year.
The officers are: President, W.
E. Pearce; Vice-President, B.
Benedict; Secretary-Treasurer, A.
S. Hammond.
It is intended to have a "live"
organization this year. Already the
boards are being brought out and
members can be seen practicing for
the major and minor tournaments,
which will begin soon. One of the
most interested players is Mr. Yokoyama, a Jananese, at the University.
Beside the major and minor
tournaments, the best of the Hopkins players will meet the University of Pennsylvania team either
over the boards or by correspondence. The minor chess team will
have • monthly matches—probably
with City College and Polytechnic.
The interclass match will be held
after Christmas. Last year, the
freshmen beat the sophomores by
the score of 8 to 1.

a letter from a large film manufacturing firm in New York, asking for the privilege of making

distributed all over the country, the
authorities are considering the matter very favorably. It should prove

and for the University, particularly
if H,opkins should win. This is
the first attempt, so far as is
known, to make pictures of a football team in action.

Arbitration Society to meet:

The first meeting of the Arbitration Society will take place tomorrow, in the Donovan Room, at
one o'clock. It has been suggested
that it might be better to change
the Society into a literary society,
or into a meeting for the discussion
of general topics. With this wider
range it is urged, a great deal more
interest would be taken by the students. A discussion of such a
change will come up at Tuesday's
meeting.
